Thus have I heard. Once, the BhagavÄn was dwelling in the Jeta Grove of AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada's Park in the city of ÅšrÄvastÄ«.
At that time, many bhiká¹£us gathered in the assembly hall and had this discussion:
The World-Honored One has explained the twelve links of dependent origination in countless ways, beginning with ignorance as the condition.
What is the reason that among the conditions for all afflictions and actions, only ignorance is said to be the condition?

The discussion of these bhiká¹£us in the assembly hall was not yet finished.

The World-Honored One, during the day, roamed in samÄdhi practice. With his heavenly ear, pure and surpassing that of humans, he heard their discussion. In the latter part of the day, he arose from samÄdhi practice, went to the dwelling hall, and, having arrived, sat in front of the assembly of bhiká¹£us on the seat that was always set up.
Having sat down, the World-Honored One said to the bhiká¹£us:
Bhiká¹£us!
Why have you gathered in the dwelling hall to discuss without finishing? What discussion was there that you gathered here?
The bhiká¹£us said:
Venerable Sir!
This large assembly of bhiká¹£us gathered in the hall to discuss, saying:
'The World-Honored One has, with innumerable approaches, explained the twelve links of dependent arising, in which he first expounds ignorance as the basis of conditions.
What is the reason that, among the conditions for all afflictions and activities, he only speaks of ignorance as the basis of conditions?
What special insight is there in this ignorance?' Venerable Sir!
We, many monks, gathered in the hall to discuss matters that had not yet been concluded, and had such discussions in this assembly.
Having said this, the World-Honored One told the monks:
There is a Dharma door called the Initial Chapter on Dependent Origination. Listen well and consider it carefully, and I will explain it to you.
What is the Dharma door of the Initial Chapter on Dependent Origination?
Monks!
There are eleven kinds of superior differences among the superior differences, therefore establishing ignorance as the initial condition for dependent origination.
What are the eleven?

Namely, the superior difference of objects, the superior difference of characteristics, the superior difference of causes, the superior difference of arising, the superior difference of transformation, the superior difference of inversions, the superior difference of characteristics, the superior difference of actions, the superior difference of obstructions, the superior difference of bondage, and the superior difference of antidotes.
At that time, a certain monk rose from his seat, adjusted his robes, bared his right shoulder, faced the World-Honored One with palms joined, and said:
Venerable One!
What is the difference in the objects of ignorance?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
The faults and evils of both causes and effects, and all the defiled aspects of both causes and effects, are all objects of ignorance.
Bhiká¹£us!
This is the difference in the objects of ignorance.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
BhagavÄn!
What is the difference in the types of ignorance?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
It covers the true and reveals the untrue.
Bhiká¹£us!
This is the difference in the types of ignorance.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
BhagavÄn!
What is the difference in the continuity of ignorance?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
It serves as the continuity, root, and dwelling place for all the defilements of afflictions, karma, and birth.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
BhagavÄn!
What are all the defilements of afflictions?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
In brief, there are three kinds of afflictions that defile all afflictions, namely, the affliction of lack of wisdom, the affliction of doubt and wisdom, and the affliction of wrong wisdom.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
BhagavÄn!
What are all the defilements of karma?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!

In brief, there are three kinds of distinctions based on their intrinsic characteristics (namely, body, speech, and mind), as well as three kinds of distinctions based on the characteristics of obstacles and antidotes (where obstacles refer to non-merit, and antidotes refer to merit and immovable [karma], which collectively encompass the defilements of karma).
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
BhagavÄn!
What are all the defilements of birth?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!

In brief, it is because of the three kinds of suffering (namely, the suffering of suffering, the suffering of change, and the suffering of the conditioned) based on the three kinds of feelings (namely, painful feelings, pleasant feelings, and neither painful nor pleasant feelings) that the defilements of birth are collectively encompassed.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable One!
How is it that all kinds of afflictive defilements, karmic defilements, and defiled birth are all caused by ignorance as their basis and fundamental abode?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!

Because of two kinds of delusion regarding the truth of reality, afflictive defilements that have not yet arisen are caused to arise, and those that have already arisen gradually increase and proliferate;
karmic defilements that have not yet arisen are caused to arise, and those that have already arisen are further accumulated;
defiled birth that has not yet arisen is caused to arise, and that which has already arisen cannot be removed.
Therefore it is said that all kinds of afflictive defilements, karmic defilements, and defiled birth are all caused by ignorance as their basis and fundamental abode.
Bhiká¹£us!
This is the superiority of ignorance as the causal condition.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable One!
What is the superiority of the arising of ignorance?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!

This ignorance, regarding the body that will be born in the future that is included in the truth of suffering, is deluded and does not understand, and regarding the body that has already been obtained in the present that is included in the truth of suffering, it is also deluded and does not understand. Due to this delusion, the arising of dependent origination and the turning out of dependent origination are combined and gathered, and the two kinds of dependent origination and the delusion regarding the bodies of the future and the present all have ignorance as the condition for their arising.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
Which is the arising of dependent origination that is combined and gathered?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!

The initial ignorance conditions formations, formations condition consciousness, and so on, up to name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, and the condition of feeling - this is called the arising of dependent origination that is combined and gathered.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
Which is the turning out of dependent origination that is combined and turned out?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!

In the second ignorance condition, from feeling as a condition there is craving, from craving as a condition there is grasping, from existence as a condition there is birth, and so on up to from birth as a condition there is old age and death. This is called the turning out conditionality, the turning out combination.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
How does the first ignorance, in that included conditionality, combine and include, and act as the arising condition?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
This one, in the body of rebirth, is deluded and does not understand seeking rebirth. Because of this delusion seeking rebirth, in rebirth one sees good things.

However, in the present, due to attachment and discrimination regarding agreeable and disagreeable objects, one creates non-meritorious actions, namely, giving rise to greed for possessions and giving rise to anger and corresponding hatred, one then acts carelessly and confusedly towards good and bad, not holding thoughts in mind.
One thinks of evil things in the other world but does not realize it. Therefore, that non-meritorious action is conditioned by ignorance.
If in the next life one sees good things or sees a way out, one then performs meritorious or immovable actions.
Or, due to the realization of the Dharma, or through one's own practice of tranquility and mindfulness, there may be a wholesome mind in that awareness and mindfulness, but it is not right thought.
Because of this, one is then led by the delusions of the next life.
That is to say, in the next life, seeing good things, one is not timid; seeing a way out, one is not timid.

Those meritorious, unmeritorious, and immovable actions - the evil opponents, antidotes, and so forth - arise and cease together with the six consciousnesses, and then place those actions within the arising and ceasing of the present retributive consciousness.
Because the newly arisen seeds are all taken in and correspond to the perfuming.
Since all the seeds are taken in, if they subsequently arise, there will be a sequence, namely, the name-and-form, six sense bases, contact, and so forth will gradually arise.

Those name-and-form, etc., in this present retribution consciousness, are only the characteristics of the cause of birth, not yet the characteristics of the effect. Therefore, it is called the conditioned arising of the aggregate.
Bhiká¹£us!
This is the first ignorance that, in the conditioned arising of the aggregate, combines and aggregates, acting as the causal condition for arising.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
How does the latter ignorance, in the conditioned arising of transformation, combine and transform, acting as the causal condition for arising?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
This one, in the present body, gives rise to delusion, and with the six sense bases and contact as conditions, gives rise to feeling, and thus obtains its flavor.
Because of obtaining the flavor, in the future one still seeks this kind of feeling.
When there is seeking, one then gives rise to grasping. In the case of pleasant feeling, craving acts as a condition and then gives rise to the grasping of desire.
What is called the grasping of desire is because of discriminating desire.
That is the foremost, and only then are there afflictions of the desire realm.

If craving for a new rebirth arises, then the practice of renunciation and disgust would not occur. This is not reasonable, because they seek the time of non-existence through craving and non-skillful means. There are two kinds of views of escape: the view of escape and the view of the basis of the two. Together there are four kinds. Because they cause this craving to take rebirth as a condition.ğŸ”½If that rebirth is the basis, and one has not yet attained detachment, then at the time of death, these four views and the afflictions of the desire realm take craving for desire as a condition to give rise to rebirth. If one is detached from desire and form, then the craving for the form realm and the craving for the formless realm always occur.
When the afflictions of the form realm and formless realm arise, then rebirth in the form realm and formless realm occurs.

The afflictions of the form and formless realms, as well as these views, may be caused by craving in the form realm to give rise to grasping, or may be caused by craving in the formless realm to give rise to grasping.
In this way, craving gives rise to grasping, and thus the perfumed and habituated karmic formations are born together with the consciousness that holds the results.

Once grasped by that grasping, the karmic formations that were previously accumulated, along with all the craving that has not yet ceased, will then manifest in that place in order to cause the self to continue to transmigrate.
For this reason, there is birth due to existence, and thus it is said that those karmic formations are existence because of the power of grasping.

Once the karmic formations become existence, then after death, the previously accumulated aggregates will be born again, and the conditions will continue to transmigrate. Therefore, it is said that birth is conditioned by existence.

In the process of transmigration, at the time of birth, the characteristics of arising are different from the past, and when one reaches the end of that life, there is death and the end of life. Therefore, it is said that old age and death are conditioned by birth.
Bhiká¹£us!
This is the second ignorance, which acts as the causal condition for the arising of the turning and emerging of the dependent origination in combination.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
Why are craving and grasping in the turning and emerging dependent origination not said to be the conditions for the formations?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
Because craving and grasping are cut off within their own realm.
Just as craving and grasping in the desire realm should not be the conditions for the formations in the form and formless realms, because they are not the objects.

Just as craving in the desire realm in the imperturbable formations, so too is craving in the form realm in the formless realm, and craving in the formless realm in the desire and form realms, and craving in the form realm in the desire realm.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
Why are craving and grasping in the desire realm not the conditions for meritorious, demeritorious, and imperturbable formations?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
In the present, regarding the objects that appear, whether loved or not, they are the dominant conditions. With the thirst for desire, unwholesome roots arise and non-meritorious actions are done.

Because in the common cause and effect of non-meritorious actions, one does not know their evil, namely the evil of mind and the evil of what is done. Because of not knowing, one performs non-meritorious actions.
But that mind and what is done evil, etc., only take ignorance as a condition, not thirst as a condition, because they do not share the same object as the unwholesome roots.

If one performs meritorious actions out of the thirst for desire, one does so based on faith, thinking that after death one will definitely be reborn, and that rebirth definitely depends on conditions. Because of being embraced by faith, all grasping and clinging are only established by me as obstacles and neutral hindrances. If dharmas are obstructed and neutral, then one is unable to perform actions.

Because in the common cause and effect of meritorious actions, one does not know how to escape, one seeks a lovable rebirth and then performs meritorious actions. Therefore, although it is called meritorious action, it also takes ignorance as a condition.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable One!
Why is the craving and grasping of the form realm not a condition for the formless realm's imperturbable actions?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
Those who have not yet freed themselves from desire have not yet given rise to craving for form and have not attained a dwelling place;
Because they have not yet attained that and have not attained a dwelling place, they are unable to be a condition for the formless realm's imperturbable actions, enabling them to arise.
Just as craving for the form realm in the form realm, so too is craving for the formless realm in the formless realm's imperturbable actions.

Because in the form realm body and formless realm body, within faults and offenses, one sees good things, thinks about them, and either due to the Dharma being taught or due to the Dharma being instructed, there is this incorrect thought, which is a condition for those actions.

However, this incorrect thought is drawn by ignorance, the fruit of incorrect thought, and is combined with ignorance. Because it is a condition for the formation of the immovable, therefore, one should know that the immovable formation also has ignorance as its condition.
Bhiká¹£us!

Moreover, one who has no craving as a basis creates meritorious and immovable formations. Because of having no craving, one sees the faults of all existences, so how would one be willing to seek future existences?

However, within non-existence, one does not know as it really is. Because of not knowing as it really is and not yet attaining the path of antidotes, one is confused about what is not an antidote and thinks it is an antidote, and then creates meritorious and immovable formations.
Bhiká¹£us!
For this reason, one should know that it is only ignorance that conditions formations, not craving and grasping as conditions.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
If formations arise together with the six consciousnesses, why is it said that formations condition consciousness?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!

Within these six consciousnesses, the practice of merit, demerit, and imperturbable [karma] combines to arise and cease together. It then places the perfuming of all practices within the consciousness of karmic retribution, creating the expedient means for attracting the newly arising consciousness of retribution. Therefore, it is said that 'practice conditions consciousness.'
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
The factors of name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, and feeling are simultaneously included in the seeds within consciousness. Why are they explained in sequence?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
Because they arise and transform in sequence in the future.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!

Why are name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, feeling, and so forth called 'birth'? The meaning of 'birth' is the general term for the entire lifetime before death, not just the initial rebirth.
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
Because they are the basis for the shared enjoyment of causes and conditions, and because they are the shared enjoyment of causes and conditions.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
If only names arise without form, what faults would there be?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
If names do not abide in form, then the continuation and transformation of dhyÄna and samÄdhi would not be appropriate.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
If only form arises without names, what faults would there be?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
If form does not unite with names, and is not grasped and sustained, then it would perish and not be able to grow.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
If only consciousness conditions the six sense bases, what faults would there be?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
At the beginning, before the six sense bases are complete, there is only the body sense base and the mind sense base, and the arising of what is transformed cannot yet be found.

The substance of these two faculties is only name-and-form at the initial stage, which serves as a condition for the subsequent satisfaction of the six sense bases. Therefore, it is said that name-and-form is a condition for the six sense bases.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
If the six sense bases are satisfied, then the Älaya-vijÃ±Äna is complete. Why is it also said that contact and feeling exist?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!

The satisfaction of the six sense bases in the Älaya-vijÃ±Äna is the satisfaction of the basis of experience, but not yet the satisfaction of experience. The satisfaction of experience is the satisfaction of the common cause of feeling. Therefore, the satisfaction of the basis of experience and the satisfaction of experience are called the satisfaction of the Älaya-vijÃ±Äna. You should understand this.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
This is the condition of ignorance giving rise to craving, and it is also said that feeling is a condition.
If only ignorance gives rise to craving, not feeling as a condition, what fault would there be?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!

The three kinds of craving and the three kinds of existence arise simultaneously, but because feeling conditions craving, when they are mutually dependent, they do not arise. Therefore, ignorance does not only condition craving.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
If only feeling conditions craving, what fault would there be?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!

All craving has feeling as its condition, but there is also feeling that is not the condition for craving, but rather becomes the condition for the cessation of craving. Therefore, feeling does not only condition craving.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
If only craving conditions existence, and not grasping, what fault would there be?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!

Thirst is called seeking. In those evil destinies, there are definitely no seekers. However, one who performs unwholesome actions, although seeking good destinies, is always in opposition to them. When the fruits transform and arise, thirst is not the condition. It is one's own grasping that causes them to transform and arise.
What the bhiká¹£u calls no thirst is called no seeking.
This absence of seeking, although in opposition, still causes the fruits of wholesome and unmoving actions to transform and arise.
Bhiká¹£u!
For this reason, do not only consider thirst to be the condition for existence.
The bhiká¹£u said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
If grasping is the condition for existence and existence is the condition for birth, why is grasping and existence not considered to be the truth of the origin?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£u!
Because thirst can perform four kinds of actions:
First, within one's own body and sense objects, it performs the action of binding to what is pleasing;
Second, within grasping at thirst, it performs the action of arising;
Third, in the midst of existence, it creates the karma that leads;
Fourth, after death, it creates the karma that binds in continuity.
Therefore, it is said that only craving is the truth of accumulation.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Bhadanta!
Why are birth, old age, and death called the characteristics of name-and-form, six sense bases, contact, and feeling, and yet all are manifested as the name of old age and death?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
The characteristics of their arising are manifested by the three sufferings in accordance with bondage.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Bhadanta!
By what suffering is birth manifested?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
It is manifested by the suffering of conditioned existence.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Bhadanta!
By what suffering is old age manifested?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
It is manifested by the suffering of change.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Bhadanta!
How is death shown by suffering?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
The suffering of suffering is shown.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Bhadanta!
What is the difference between the four kinds of birth and birth, old age, and death?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
Those four kinds of birth arise in sequence. If birth arises in accordance with similarity, the characteristic of birth in that birth should be known to be like this.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Bhadanta!
What does the sequential arising of birth look like?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
That initial planting of the seed is precisely birth. That which subsequently grows is birth;
that which subsequently emerges from the womb is birth; that which subsequently grows is birth.
Having grown, one is able to experience worldly birth.
What is the birth that arises in sequence?
The aggregates, elements, and sense bases arise without a self. Why is this?
Because the five aggregates and so forth increase and flow, they are impermanent;
And because the life faculty, strength, limits, time, and duration are also produced by impermanence.
Bhiká¹£us!
Those four characteristics of birth are destroyed by time and produce five kinds of decline, called old age.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
BhagavÄn!
What are the five kinds of decline?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
First, the decline of hair, because the color of the hair changes;
Second, the decline of the body, because the color and strength of the flesh and bones decline;

Third, the decline of karma, because when speaking, one pants and gasps, when standing, one is bent like an ox's back, when sitting, one leans forward heavily, when walking, one supports oneself on a staff, and the mind and wisdom are bound and one's mindfulness is weak;

Fourth, the degeneration of experience, because one experiences inferior things among present possessions, does not experience any enjoyable games, and does not quickly engage in or disengage from the objects of the sense faculties;
Fifth, the degeneration of the life faculty, because one is unable to endure the approach of death as one's life ends, and death from minor causes.
Bhiká¹£us!
Among those four kinds of characteristics of birth, there are also six kinds of distinctions in death that should be known.

First, death by exhaustion; second, death not by exhaustion; third, death by intrinsic nature; fourth, the portion of death not by exhaustion; fifth, the portion of death by exhaustion; sixth, untimely or timely death.
Bhiká¹£us!
Among them, death by intrinsic nature means that consciousness moves out of the body to a different part, and the sense faculties cease. This should be known.
Bhiká¹£us!
The characteristics of the birth of name-and-form and so forth have this distinction from birth, old age, and death. The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable One!
All three kinds of craving are said to be the causes for birth and arising. Why is it only said that birth in the desire realm exists?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
Because birth in the desire realm is coarse, it cannot be praised or taught, because it is a turning back, not the essence of the Dharma of liberation.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable One!
If this appropriation-based dependent arising and the twelve factors of dependent arising are explained, how many of them are the factors of appropriation and how many are the appropriated factors?
How many are the factors of turning out and how many are the turned-out factors?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
Ignorance, karmic formations, and a part of consciousness are the factors of appropriation;
That part of consciousness, name-and-form, the six sense bases, contact, and feeling are the appropriated factors.
Bhiká¹£us!
That part of feeling, craving, grasping, and becoming are the factors of turning out;
Birth, old age, and death are the parts that are turned out, and a part of them, namely name-and-form, six sense bases, contact, and feeling, are also the parts that are turned out, you should know.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
Are these parts that gather and accumulate and these parts that are turned out seen to arise simultaneously, or are they sequential?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
They arise simultaneously, but are explained sequentially.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!

Since the parts that gather and accumulate and the parts that are turned out arise simultaneously, why is it that the parts that gather and accumulate are explained first, and the parts that are turned out are explained later?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
Because there is turning out due to the accumulation, therefore there is no turning out without accumulation.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
Why is it said that ignorance conditions wrong thought, and that it acts as a condition for ignorance?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
Because of ignorance, due to the pulling of incorrect thought, it becomes a condition for action. From ignorance, contact, feeling, and craving are born, and it becomes a condition.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
BhagavÄn!
How many aspects of the brief explanation of dependent arising should be known?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
The brief explanation of three aspects of dependent arising should be known:

First, the aspect of immovable dependent arising, which is the meaning of emptiness, because of emptiness there is no movement; second, the aspect of impermanent dependent arising; third, the aspect of capable dependent arising.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
BhagavÄn!

There are four kinds of conditions spoken of by the BhagavÄn, namely causal condition, immediate condition (formerly called sequential condition), object condition, and dominant condition (also called arising condition).
BhagavÄn!
Among them, by what kind of condition does ignorance become a condition for action?
Up to what conditions give rise to old age and death as conditions?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
Because the arising and transformation of all conditioned phenomena have the same characteristics, I speak of four kinds of conditions.
In this meaning, I explain the dominant condition as the condition of ignorance for volitional formations, up to the condition of birth for old age and death.
That dominant condition also has non-attachment and attachment.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Bhadanta!
What is the non-attachment dominant condition?
What is the attachment dominant condition?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
In the non-arising of incorrect thought, the latent tendency of ignorance is non-attached to the volitional formations as a condition;
if it has already arisen, then it is attached.
Bhiká¹£us!
The incorrect thought combines with the volitional formations, and together they arise in the six sense bases. Having arisen but not yet ceased, it is non-attached to consciousness as a condition;
if it has arisen and ceased, then it is attached.
Bhiká¹£us!

The consciousness that has not yet reached the time of death, does not attach to name-and-form and acts as a condition for consciousness, and name-and-form acts as a condition for consciousness. The Sanskrit text also lacks this sentence. As consciousness is to name-and-form, so is name-and-form to the collection of name-and-form, and so is name-and-form to the emerging of name-and-form.
As name-and-form is to name-and-form, so are the six sense bases to the six sense bases, contact to contact, and feeling to feeling.
As ignorance is to volitional formations, so is ignorance to craving, craving to grasping, and grasping to becoming.
As consciousness is to name-and-form, and name-and-form, etc. are to name-and-form, etc., so is becoming to birth.
Moreover, bhiká¹£us!
In birth, the womb, childhood, and youth, do not attach to old age and death and act as conditions;
When reaching the time of ripe faculties and the end of life, they act as conditions for each other. You should know this.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
Venerable!
If the World-Honored One has ever, within the Dharma gates of common causes and conditions, spoken of karma due to craving, what is the hidden meaning in that?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!
The karma that is included in existence is spoken of due to craving. This is the hidden meaning.
The bhiká¹£us said to the Buddha:
BhagavÄn!ğŸ”½What is the meaning of 'cause' that can be seen?
What is the meaning of 'condition' that can be seen?
What is the meaning of 'basis' that can be seen?
The Buddha said:
Bhiká¹£us!ğŸ”½Because it establishes the seeds for future births, the meaning of 'cause' can be seen;
Because it determines and upholds the turning out of that birth, the meaning of 'condition' can be seen;
